word.entryDescription: a time phrase used to introduce / link events
word.entryExample: Shortly afterwards he started conducting experiments.

word.entryDescription: trousers which do not cover the lower part of your legs
word.entryExample: I don't have nice shorts for summer.

word.entryDescription: it is a good idea to
word.entryExample: What should you do if you've got a headache?

word.entryDescription: the part of your body where your arm joins your chest
word.entryExample: I carry my bag over my shoulder.

word.entryDescription: a small piece of thick cloth that is fixed inside the shoulders of dress or jacket to make a person’s shoulders look bigger
word.entryExample: In some societies males wear shoulder pads and epaulets to broaden their frame.

word.entryDescription: to say something with a loud voice or cry
word.entryExample: The pirate shouted, 'There's the treasure!'

word.entryDescription: to let something be seen
word.entryExample: Can you show me the pictures from your last holiday?

word.entryDescription: a performance or an exhibition
word.entryExample: The sisters were both in a talent show.

word.entryDescription: a piece of equipment that produces a flow of water you stand under to wash yourself
word.entryExample: I have a shower after I get up every morning.

word.entryDescription: a short period of reasonably heavy rain or snow
word.entryExample: There was a quick shower and then the sun appeared again.

word.entryDescription: a small sea creature that can be eaten; it has ten legs and a soft shell, and turns pink when cooked
word.entryExample: The penguins need the ice too, as their principal food, krill, a type of small shrimp, lives under it.

word.entryDescription: (past simple 'shrank', past participle 'shrunk') to become smaller
word.entryExample: By 2050, primary forests will have been shrinking gradually.

word.entryDescription: uncomfortable, nervous and embarrassed with other people, particularly new people
word.entryExample: Because he is a quiet person, people think he is shy.

word.entryDescription: a brother or sister
word.entryExample: I haven't got any siblings. I'm an only child.

word.entryDescription: in poor health
word.entryExample: We're sick. We've both caught the flu.

word.entryDescription: plural for 'side dish' – a food served with the main course, often on a separate plate
word.entryExample: Side dishes commonly used with main courses in many countries of the western world are for example salad, potatoes or bread.

word.entryDescription: an activity in which you go round a place looking at its famous sights
word.entryExample: You'll need a few days if you want to go sightseeing in Rome.

word.entryDescription: a thing with a name or information outside a house, shop, etc
word.entryExample: There's a large sign above the door.

word.entryDescription: your name written by you in a way which always looks the same, and which you use to show that you have written or agreed to something
word.entryExample: End your letter 'Yours sincerely', then write your signature.

word.entryDescription: having meaning; important enough to have an effect or to be noticed
word.entryExample: The non-work travel is becoming a much more significant part of the total travel.

word.entryDescription: a soft, smooth and shiny material made from thread produced by certain caterpillars
word.entryExample: She's wearing a silk dress.

word.entryDescription: not sensible, acting like a child
word.entryExample: Sam sometimes is very silly!

word.entryDescription: made of or the colour of silver
word.entryExample: The second person gets a silver medal.

word.entryDescription: an older person who searches the internet
word.entryExample: The number of silver surfers has increased dramatically over the past several years due to their being more accustomed to the technology.

word.entryDescription: almost the same
word.entryExample: Local villagers still use similar pots to those used in the past.

word.entryDescription: from a time in the past until a later time, or until now
word.entryExample: It's been a tradition since 1605.

word.entryDescription: to make music with your voice, usually with words
word.entryExample: I love to sing pop songs.

word.entryDescription: somebody who sings, usually as a job
word.entryExample: This singer is the best in the band.

word.entryDescription: used at the beginning of a formal letter written to a man you do not know
word.entryExample: If you don't know the name of the person to whom you are writing, write 'Dear Sir/Madam'.

word.entryDescription: a woman or girl who has the same parents as you
word.entryExample: My sister Anna is ten years old.

word.entryDescription: your brother's wife, or your husband or wife's sister
word.entryExample: Barbara is Rebecca's sister-in-law.

word.entryDescription: to move your body into a sitting position
word.entryExample: Sit down and read your book.

word.entryDescription: a place where a builiding, town, etc. is, was or will be located
word.entryExample: In 1904, US president Theodore Roosevelt visited the construction site of the Panama Canal.

word.entryDescription: = living room (a room at home in which people sit and relax)
word.entryExample: There are two computers in my house. They're in the sitting room and my bedroom.

word.entryDescription: the section in a newspaper where jobs are advertised; the title of this section
word.entryExample: I turned to the Situations Vacant page.

word.entryDescription: the number 6
word.entryExample: My aunt has six children.

word.entryDescription: the number 16
word.entryExample: We live sixteen kilometres away from the sea.

word.entryDescription: in the position of number six when we count
word.entryExample: June is the sixth month.

word.entryDescription: how big or small something is
word.entryExample: These jeans are too small. Can I try on a bigger size?

word.entryDescription: to move on special boots across ice or hard flat surfaces
word.entryExample: Can you skate well?

word.entryDescription: one of a pair of boots with a blade or wheel on the bottom which you use to skate with
word.entryExample: Do you have any skates?

word.entryDescription: a short board with a pair of wheels at each end, which you stand on and ride
word.entryExample: Don't ride your skateboard at home!

word.entryDescription: somebody who skates on ice
word.entryExample: She's my favourite skater.

word.entryDescription: a sport or activity in which you skate on ice or hard flat surfaces
word.entryExample: I don't do much sport, but I like going skiing and skating in the winter.

word.entryDescription: an area of ice used for ice skating
word.entryExample: I move on the skating rink very slowly.

word.entryDescription: a resort developed for skiing, snowboarding, and other winter sports; with lodging and all the necessary facilities
word.entryExample: This is the best ski resort for beginners.

word.entryDescription: a sport or activity in which you move on skis
word.entryExample: I went skiing and I hurt myself badly.

word.entryDescription: an ability to do something well, often something that you have practised
word.entryExample: I believe I would be a good teacher because I have good people skills.

word.entryDescription: describes someone who is too thin
word.entryExample: I'm skinny and I've got a big nose but I don't care what I look like.

word.entryDescription: to turn a rope and jump over it many times
word.entryExample: I can skip very fast.
